comments.text:
+WikeddTung Childish ad hominems aside,  your proposition is ridiculous. 
You're saying that when somebody moves to a new community, that they depend 
for survival upon the grace of the community into which they move or by 
leeching off them? What palpable nonsense.

Tell that to Elon Musk, tell it to Albert Einstein, tell it to Madeline 
Albright, tell it to any of the hundreds of sports and entertainment stars 
that are imported to the US from the rest of the planet, tell it to any 
hardworking entrepreneur who has forged our a career for himself in a 
country other than the one in which he was born.

What about when they arrive with wealth and skills of their own? People are 
not even generally allowed to immigrate to the US unless they can prove 
that they are essential, or will enrich the nation. That's not "at the US's 
grace", that's the US WANTING to attract the cream of the crop from across 
the planet.

Your argument makes as much sense as suggesting that the US is "graciously" 
allowing China to thrive by borrowing money from it. The fact is, the US 
wanted and needed what the Jews had to offer (and yes, to be fair, it also 
offered a hand to many of them after WW2). If Jews thrived from that point, 
it's not because they were parasites. It's because they had the business 
acumen and determination to do so. Frankly for you to argue anything else, 
insults your own race by painting them as powerless victims against the 
unstoppable Jewish business mind. They had no greater opportunities than 
anyone else, and when you portray them as "parasites", what you're actually 
saying is, "Given worse opportunities, they managed to do better than the 
natives. Therefore, I hate them."

Perhaps if you could suspend your own biases and your blatant inferiority 
complex, you might realise that.

By no means am I claiming that the Jews are some super race, or that there 
are not Jewish cultural practices that I dislike, but to portray them as 
some global bogey man belittles your own culture.

Funny.

comment is implying.

Or you know... how 11 million Soviets died in World War 2 fighting off the 
Nazis... was that genocide too?
How about the Vietnam War? They estimate at least a million Vietnamese 
died, is that genocide too?

comments.text:

"Denying Armenian Genocide is like denying the holocaust"
I don't personally don't deny the death of many Armenians, that did happen 
and that is fact, but I don't see it as a genocide.
It was basically a fucked up civil war and the eastern side of the Ottoman 
was in turmoil, the Ottomans main intentions were to never wipe out the 
Armenians, both sides were just slaughtering each other.
Meanwhile in Nazi Germany, Hitler was a heavy aggressor of war, deeply 
planned out the holocaust (He had companies bid for the contract on gas 
chambers), cracked down on every person that was deemed imperfect, sent 
them off to camps where they were used as slaves, tested on, tortured and 
many were eventually killed...
Also, think what you want about the term 'Young Turks' but the fact remains 
that it's used to signify progressiveness and revolution... it even holds a 
dictionary definition.
There was in a group of Republicans back in the 60's had a group called 
'The Young Turks' because they hoped for reform in the GOP.

comments.text:

stifle the inquisitive mind.

short period (~800-1200 ce) Islam is if anything a far greater force in the 
world that it was at this time. Why doesn't it contribute proportionally?

If you don't accept this as true, compare the number of Nobel prize winners 
of (supposed) Jewish descent against those of (supposed) Muslim descent as 
a proportion of their respective global populations. If you aren't shocked 
by those figures YOU SHOULD BE.

should be any less intelligent or capable than someone brought up with a 
Jewish background. Yet the Muslim world continues to underperform. Why do 
you think this is?
